text: Personally, the commuter rail wasn’t bad (Fitchburg line) pre-covid and was my preferred way of in/out. I worked in the North End and could walk to North Station and out. I got out of the city faster than by car, even when I moved to Cambridge (I’d take it to Porter and hop off there), which was an easy drive to Somerville, Arlington, or North / West Cambridge.

text:
Re local metro--

Don't expect a comfortable commute if you find a place on the green line. That sucker is amazingly slow, and can get as packed as a Tokyo subway when Red Sox season comes around. This is not a joke-- and it can happen on the hottest days of the year. Avoid avoid avoid.

Red line is not so bad outside outside of city central, but can get very packed all the way through Harvard-->MGH-->South Station area. It's not as uncomfortable as the green line, but those stations can be really trying.

Orange line is ancient-- although theyre rolling out some modern cars. It does have long trains with mostly enough space, although, again, it can get kind of uncomfortable during the summer around city center.

Don't have much experience with the blue line, although what I have had is pretty good, fast, spacey, air conditioned.

text: If you're driving and don't have parking at work, expect to pay for it with money, time, gritted teeth, and tears. Old, unplanned, tight roads do not make for good parking opportunities. Sounds like you might be around Seaport, which is a little better, but I definitely have trouble around there sometimes.
